title: Fix notebook code actions on save not triggering for LSP servers
body:
Fixes #216653 and astral-sh/ruff-vscode#51 where code actions (like source.organizeImports and source.fixAll) from LSP servers like Ruff were not being triggered when saving notebook files.

The problem was that notebook save participants were using CodeActionTriggerType.Invoke for all code actions, but many LSP servers filter their actions based on trigger type.

This change uses different trigger types based on the code action kind:
- CodeActionTriggerType.Invoke for notebook-specific actions (notebook.*) to preserve cross-cell editing capabilities (addresses #183855)
- CodeActionTriggerType.Auto for regular LSP actions (source.*) to match standard save participant behavior

Resolves issues with extensions like Ruff not organizing imports or applying fixes on notebook save when configured in notebook.codeActionsOnSave.

<!-- Thank you for submitting a Pull Request. Please:
* Read our Pull Request guidelines:
  https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/How-to-Contribute#pull-requests
* Associate an issue with the Pull Request.
* Ensure that the code is up-to-date with the `main` branch.
* Include a description of the proposed changes and how to test them.
-->

labels.description: Verification succeeded

labels.name: insiders-released
labels.description: Patch has been released in VS Code Insiders

body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates -->
<!-- Please attach logs to help us diagnose your issue -->

- Copilot Chat Extension Version:   0.30.2025080501
- VS Code Version:
```
Version: 1.103.0-insider (user setup)
Commit: 34769c5d17df269aed44407eb1a1c0e6362e2d79
Date: 2025-08-04T21:43:35.566Z
Electron: 37.2.3
ElectronBuildId: 12035395
Chromium: 138.0.7204.100
Node.js: 22.17.0
V8: 13.8.500258-electron.0
OS: Windows_NT x64 10.0.26100
```
- OS Version: 
- Feature (e.g. agent/edit/ask mode): Manage models
- Selected model (e.g. GPT 4.1, Claude 3.7 Sonnet): n/a
- Logs:

Steps to Reproduce:


1. My extension implements the LanguageModelChatProvider2 interface by following [this example](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-extension-samples/blob/main/chat-model-provider-sample/package.json)
2. But our extension only activates on files
```
workspaceContains:some_files
```
3. When I some extensions list the models provided by our extension, for example, opening GitHub Copilot Chat => Manage Models quick pick, at this time, if our extension is not automatically activated, so it won't be able to show models provided by our extension.

However, if I manually activate my extension and then click Manage Models, it works well.

Is there an activationEvent when other extension uses our chat provider? Is there any other workaround than setting activationEvents to "*".

I am working in a workspace that has the following structure:
```
.eslintrc.json

	support/

			email-config.json

			env.ts
			lighthouse.configs.ts
		misc/
			apps.ts
			channels.ts
			constants.ts
			entities.ts
			httpRequests.ts
			payload.helpers.ts
			request.helpers.ts
			utils.ts
		pages/
			adminitration/
			common/
			console/
			storefront/
		types/
			channels.d.ts
	tests/
		administration/
			agentGroups.spec.ts
			directoryNumbers.spec.ts
			interactionFlows.spec.ts
			permissions.spec.ts
		console/
			applechat.spec.ts
			...
		perf/
			...
		storefront/
```"},{"role":"user","content":"
In this example, we're debugging a simple Python file, so we only need a launch.json:

Here's a description of the app I want to debug: "python file"
In my workspace I have the files main.py, tox.ini, and README.md.



Here is your `launch.json` configuration:
```json
{
	"type": "python",
	"request": "launch",
	"name": "Launch Program",
	"program": "${workspaceFolder}/main.py"
}
```





In this example, generate both a launch.json and tasks.json because the program needs to be built before it can be debugged:

Here's a description of the app I want to debug: "my-program"
In my workspace I have the files Makefile, my-program.cpp.



Here is your `launch.json` configuration:
```json
{
	"configurations": [
		{
			"type": "cppvsdbg",
			"request": "launch",
			"name": "Launch Program",
			"program": "${workspaceFolder}/my-program.exe",
			"preLaunchTask": "build"
		}
	]
}
```
It looks like you build your project using your Makefile, so let's add a `tasks.json` to do that before each debug session:
```json
{
	"tasks": [
		{
			"type": "shell",
			"label": "build",
			"command": "make",
			"args": [
				"build"
			]
		}
	]
}
```



"},{"role":"user","content":"Find an existing launch config for my app or create one based on my project stucture and workspace"}]

title: Multi-Root Workspaces: glob and file search not working

labels.name: info-needed
labels.description: Issue requires more information from poster

body:
- Copilot Chat Extension Version: github.copilot: 1.350.0, github.copilot-chat: 0.29.1
- VS Code Version: 1.102.3
- OS Version: Win11
- Feature (e.g. agent/edit/ask mode): agent
- Selected model (e.g. GPT 4.1, Claude 3.7 Sonnet): Claude Sonnet 4

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a Multi-Root Workspaces file in vs code with at least 2 folders
eg: 
`{
    "folders": [
        {
            "path": "../workspace-one"
        },
        {
            "path": "../workspace-two"
        }
    ]
}`
3. Create a python file in every workspace that only contains a comment: "test-string"
4. Let copilot search that string inside workspace one. He will create and show a glob search pattern like this: `test-string **/workspace-one/**`
This pattern means he is searching test-string inside any workspace-one folder.
But he will not have any results, because the pattern should look like this for workspaces: `./workspace-one/**`

I looked a this documentation and it is specified that searches in Multi-Root Workspaces have to start with ./{workspace_name} and not the usual glop pattern of `**/{folder_name}` seen here: https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/editing/workspaces/multi-root-workspaces#_search
But Github copilot in VS code always appends a `**` at the beginning of the glob and file search which breaks the possibility to search in Multi-Root Workspaces. So after the hardcoded adding of the two stars he tries to search when instructed correctly with: `**./{workspace-one}/**` which still wont result anything because of the first two stars. 

I found it hardcoded addition of two stars in these files:
vscode-copilot-chat\src\extension\tools\node\findTextInFilesTool.tsx line 114
vscode-copilot-chat\src\extension\tools\node\findFilesTool.tsx line 70

The only way copilot file search finds anything is when he searches in subfolders of any workspace, than the glob pattern works because it is a folder and not a root workspace. So when he searches for `**/sub_folder_name/**` he gets results. which you usually would search as ./workspace-one/subfolder_name/**

Working with Multi-Root Workspaces and copliot is very important for me to have the full capability to solve issues over multiple projects that have some kind of dependencies on each other. For me this is a show stopper to work efficiently with this tool.

title: `vscode.workspace.onWillSaveTextDocument()` broken on untitled documents
body:
`vscode.workspace.onWillSaveTextDocument()` doesn't execute when attempting to save an untitled document


Steps to Reproduce:

1. create extension with code
  ```ts
context.subscriptions.push(
	vscode.workspace.onWillSaveTextDocument((textDocumentWillSaveEvent) => {
		console.log("User attempted to save a file");
		console.log(textDocumentWillSaveEvent);
	})
);
```
2. start the extension
3. open a untitled file
4. hit ctrl+s save

Expected:
Console logs a `textDocumentWillSaveEvent`

Actual:
nothing

opening a file from disk and pressing ctrl+s save works as expected

Reason:
I would like to be able to supply a default filename, location and extension when the user ctrl+s saves a untitled file
(that is assigned to my language)
via the `vscode.window.showSaveDialog()` function
however there is no way to detect a save without overriding the ctrl+s shortcut
and obviously that won't work anyway

Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes
- VS Code Version: v1.102.3
- OS Version: Windows 11

title: How to stop GitHub Copilot from auto installing on remote server
body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates -->
<!-- Please attach logs to help us diagnose your issue -->

- Copilot Chat Extension Version: 1.350.0
- VS Code Version: 1.102.3
- OS Version: Windows 11 26100.4770
- Feature (e.g. agent/edit/ask mode): 
- Selected model (e.g. GPT 4.1, Claude 3.7 Sonnet):
- Logs:

I have a very cheap VPS, and it has about 1GB memory. When using remote SSH, with only the GitHub Copilot extension, it constantly crashes because of OOM. This is also discussed [here](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-copilot-release/issues/4627), though that is not what I want to discuss. The point is, I can't remove it from the remote server. 

If I uninstall it, it will be automatically reinstalled the next time remote SSH connects.
If I disable it, it will be disabled on my host too, even if I am not connecting to the server.

Is there any way I can stop it from auto-installing? Just like any other extension which shows a button that lets you decide whether to install on the remote server or not.

title: Copilot Chat GPT-4 edits unrelated parts of JSON file instead of fixing the actual syntax error
body:
Type: Bug ### 🐞 Bug Report #### Title Copilot Chat GPT-4 edits unrelated parts of JSON file instead of fixing the actual syntax error --- ### 📋 Steps to Reproduce 1. Open the following file in VS Code: `c:/Users/ramaa/Documents/graphen_hybrid_aplication/src/shared_data/methods/reductions/ECR/ECR_application_profiles.json` 2. Note the error reported by the JSON language service: ``` End of file expected. Line: 11, Column: 8 ``` 3. Open **GitHub Copilot Chat** using **GPT-4.0** or **GPT-4.1 Free** and prompt: ``` please fix this ``` 4. Observe that Copilot responds: ``` The JSON syntax error in ECR\_application\_profiles.json has been fixed... ``` 5. Review the edit: - The error **on line 11** is **not fixed**. - Copilot edits **a different, unrelated part** of the file instead. - In some cases, valid parts of the code are broken. --- ### 💡 Expected Behavior Copilot should: - Fix the actual issue reported by the VS Code JSON parser (e.g., add or close brackets as needed), - Or clearly state it cannot determine the exact error location and decline to make changes. --- ### ❌ Actual Behavior - Copilot confidently claims the error is fixed, - But edits the wrong part of the file, - The original error persists, - Sometimes new syntax issues are introduced. --- ### 🔁 Reproducibility This behavior is consistently reproducible in: - GPT-4.0 - GPT-4.1 (Free version) --- ### ✅ Other Notes - When I tested the same prompt and file with **Claude Sonnet (Anthropic)** or other **premium models**, they handled the file **correctly** and resolved the issue based on the line error. - However, those models are **not available in Copilot Chat** and are **usage-limited**, so I rely on GitHub Copilot Chat to handle this task reliably. - This discrepancy strongly suggests a **model-specific misalignment** in GPT-4's ability to parse and follow file diagnostics in VS Code. --- ### 📌 Suggestion Please improve the Copilot Chat integration so that GPT-4 can: - Accurately read diagnostics from the editor (line and column), - Avoid editing unrelated parts of the file, - And gracefully decline when it cannot confidently fix the error. ``` Extension version: 0.29.1 VS Code version: Code 1.102.3 (488a1f239235055e34e673291fb8d8c810886f81, 2025-07-29T03:00:23.339Z) OS version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.26100 Modes:

title: Add Option to Include Recently Closed in Recently Opened List

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

labels.name: workbench-history
labels.description: History item issues

milestone.title: Backlog Candidates
milestone.description: Work that is not yet accepted for the Backlog. We wait for the community to weigh in.

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
My computer remains on for extended periods, and I typically keep several windows open continuously while opening/closing other windows temporarily. However, when upgrading VSCode, I need to close all windows first. After completing the upgrade and restarting, I can no longer find those previously closed windows (which were long-running) in the "Recently Opened" list, as they've been pushed out by temporary windows.

This feature request proposes adding an option to include recently closed items in the "Recently Opened" list to better preserve workflow continuity.

title: GitHub Copilot returns repeated "response matched public code" without response, still charging usage
body:
Type: Performance Issue Issue Summary: GitHub Copilot keeps returning the message: Sorry, the response matched public code so it was blocked. Please rephrase your prompt. Learn more. This happens repeatedly (6–7 times in a row) even after rephrasing the prompt. However, despite not providing any code completions, Copilot still counts the activity towards my usage and subscription. Steps to Reproduce: Open a code file in VS Code. Use Copilot to generate code by writing a natural language prompt. Receive the same message repeatedly with no actual output. Check GitHub usage or subscription — activity is still being logged/charged. Expected Behavior: Copilot should not count blocked responses towards user activity or billing. If Copilot cannot respond, the user should not be charged or have activity recorded. There should be a setting to disable public code matching if the result is unusable anyway. Actual Behavior: Copilot blocks the response each time with the same message. User receives no actual code back. Despite this, usage is still logged under my paid subscription. body: Type: Feature Request I use gpt4o to translate my app to english language. I have got lot of trouble which makes my work hard to do. Type: Feature Request Functional Requirements for Qt TS Multilingual File Editing and Product Optimization 1. Intelligent Chunking and Batch Processing of TS Files Automatically split large TS files into specified line ranges or logical blocks for loading and editing, reducing lag and memory usage. Support batch translation and auto-completion of tags, skipping variable names and identifiers that do not require translation. 2. Smart Detection and Highlighting of Untranslated Content Automatically detect all entries with type="unfinished", list them in batches, and support one-click completion or manual review. Highlight untranslated content for quick location and processing. 3. Context Caching and Resume Support The editor should automatically record progress, allowing users to resume from where they left off, avoiding re-analysis of the entire file each time. Cache context to ensure translation accuracy by referencing surrounding content. 4. Multilingual Collaboration and Terminology Integration Support collaborative editing, synchronize terminology libraries and professional vocabulary to ensure translation consistency. Automatically match and suggest terms from the terminology library to reduce manual lookup and repetitive work. 5. Performance Optimization Optimize VS Code or related editors for handling large XML/TS files, reducing lag, delays, and crashes. Support asynchronous loading and background processing to improve editing experience. 6. Automation Scripts and AI Integration Provide official Python/Node.js script templates for automatic chunking, batch translation, and completion. Integrate with AI translation APIs, enabling automatic translation using Copilot, Claude, Gemini, etc. 7. User Experience and Interaction Optimization Support one-click “Continue with next chunk” to reduce manual intervention and improve automation. Provide progress bars, processing logs, and error prompts to help users track task progress. title: Coding agent integration tries to create changes on a PR that doesn't exist
body: Steps to Reproduce: 1. Create a Padawan PR from main. 2. Open the branch for that Padawan PR with the GitHub PR extension in VS Code. 3. Merge the PR on GitHub.com, and delete that branch. 4. Ask #copilotCodingAgent to create a new PR. Expected - Coding agent creates a new PR against main successfully. Actual - Coding agent tries to create a PR against a PR number that doesn't exist (PR 2, original was PR 1). Next, I switched to `main` to try and kick off the coding agent. It failed with a different error: Ultimately, restarting VS Code fixed the issue.

title: Feature Request: Delete File by URL Reference

labels.name: markdown
labels.description: Markdown support issues

labels.name: *extension-candidate
labels.description: Issue identified as good extension implementation

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

In VS Code, after pasting an image into a Markdown document, you can undo the action to simultaneously remove both the image file and the inserted reference. However, once further edits are made, these deletions must be done manually. I would like to propose a new command: when a user selects a URL and right-clicks, they should be able to delete both the string and the associated file.

## Proposed Behavior

If the reference count for the file is 1:
  - Delete the URL string from the Markdown
  - Delete the actual file from disk

If the file is referenced by other Markdown documents:
  - Show a confirmation dialog with the following options:
      - View all references (to help navigate and make informed edits)
      - Delete the file
      - Cancel (no action taken)

Most images are only referenced once, so this feature would improve many Markdown workflows by making media deletion more intuitive, similar to the behavior in Word or other editors.

## Extended Proposal

This functionality could also apply to any place a URL is used, such as:

- File imports in code (e.g., JavaScript/TypeScript)
- CSS and HTML resource links
    
It's highly recommended that this feature be built into VS Code as a native capability to streamline file management across multiple editing scenarios.

title: AI Quick Chat shows files from previously opened projects instead of current workspace
body:
Type: Bug # AI Quick Chat shows files from previously opened projects instead of current workspace ## Bug Description When using AI Quick Chat (Popup) or the chat panel, the file suggestions and context results show files from previously opened projects/workspaces instead of limiting results to the current active workspace. ## Steps to Reproduce 1. Open a project/workspace in VSCode 2. Open AI Quick Chat (Popup) or use the chat panel 3. Try to add context using "#" or click "Add context" 4. Search for files (e.g., "readme", "package.json", etc.) ## Expected Behavior The file suggestions should only show files from the current active workspace/project. ## Actual Behavior The suggestions display files from previously opened projects/workspaces, including files from completely different directories (as shown in the screenshots: files from `/Downloads/drx.reactlynx-snippets-0.0.4/`, `/Documents/bastindev/VScode/lynx-keymap-75/`, etc.). ## Impact - Confusing user experience - Risk of accidentally including wrong files as context - Cluttered and irrelevant suggestions - Makes it difficult to find files from the current project ## Environment - VSCode Version: [your version] - AI Chat Extension Version: [extension version] - OS: [your operating system] ## Screenshots ![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/b408ba01-cab9-4670-8d81-2318fbde75af) ![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/99b292c3-606d-425e-b516-6c71fff62372) ![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/53f7507a-c118-4987-965f-94aa330633e8) ![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/f2ed0408-3b34-4d8a-a8f8-d0725e078cbc) ## Additional Notes This issue occurs in both the AI Quick Chat popup and the chat panel. It affects all file types, not just README files - as shown in the screenshots, package.json files and other file types from different projects also appear in the suggestions. title: Make ${workspaceFolder} resolve to the .code-workspace file location in multi-root workspaces

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

labels.name: tasks
labels.description: Task system issues

milestone.title: Backlog Candidates
milestone.description: Work that is not yet accepted for the Backlog. We wait for the community to weigh in.

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
## 🧩 Feature Request: Make `${workspaceFolder}` resolve to the `.code-workspace` file location in multi-root workspaces

### 📝 Summary

In multi-root workspaces, when defining tasks directly in the `.code-workspace` file, `${workspaceFolder}` currently resolves to the **first folder listed** in `"folders"`. This behavior is unintuitive and error-prone. I propose that `${workspaceFolder}` should instead resolve to the **folder containing the `.code-workspace` file itself**, which is a clear and unambiguous context.

---

### 🔍 Current Behavior

- `${workspaceFolder}` resolves to the first folder in `"folders"` array.
- This can lead to incorrect path resolutions when tasks are defined in the `.code-workspace` file.
- Users must work around this by using `${workspaceFolder:folderName}`, which adds verbosity and complexity.

---

### ✅ Proposed Behavior

- When used inside the `.code-workspace` file, `${workspaceFolder}` should resolve to the folder containing that file.
- This would make task paths and other configurations more predictable and ergonomic.

---

### 💡 Benefits

- Eliminates ambiguity in multi-root setups.
- Aligns with user expectations—tasks defined in the workspace file should belong to the workspace.
- Reduces need for scoped variable workarounds.
- Improves maintainability and clarity of workspace-level configurations.

---

### 🧪 Example

```json
{
  "folders": [
    { "path": "project-a" },
    { "path": "project-b" }
  ],
  "tasks": {
    "version": "2.0.0",
    "tasks": [
      {
        "label": "build",
        "command": "${workspaceFolder}/scripts/build.sh"
      }
    ]
  }
}
```
Expected resolution: ${workspaceFolder} → folder containing .code-workspace Current resolution: ${workspaceFolder} → project-a

title: Consolidate File Changes response part

labels.name: debt
labels.description: Code quality issues

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body: In https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/pull/257906 we introduced a new chat response type which allow extensions to contribute "File Changes" part in response streams. The "File Changes" part presents a set of changed files (their original and modified Uri). The "File Changes" response part is nearly identical to how @aiday-mar designed the Checkout File Changes, which is richer in its presentation (e.g., changed lines). We should look into how to consolidate these two parts.

title: Emoji Corruption

labels.name: info-needed
labels.description: Issue requires more information from poster

body:
# 🐛 Bug Report: VS Code Emoji Corruption Across Multiple File Types

## Summary
VS Code's text rendering engine corrupts emoji characters across multiple file types, causing parsing failures, garbled file content with duplicate text sections, and silent data corruption.

## Environment
- **VS Code Version**: [Current stable version]
- **OS**: macOS 14.6.0 (Darwin 24.6.0)
- **File Types Affected**: 
  - `.j2` (Jinja2 templates)
  - `.py` (Python source files)
  - `.md` (Markdown documentation)
  - `.txt` (Plain text files)
- **Extensions**: GitHub Copilot, Python, Jinja2 syntax highlighting, Markdown support
- **Encoding**: UTF-8

## Issue Description

### Problem
When working with files containing emoji characters across multiple file types, VS Code's text rendering corrupts the emoji display and file content, resulting in:

1. **Broken emoji characters** displayed as `�` (replacement character U+FFFD)
2. **Content duplication** with garbled text sections
3. **File parsing failures** when the corrupted files are processed
4. **Silent file corruption** that persists across sessions
5. **Cross-file-type impact** affecting templates, source code, documentation, and configuration files
6. **Secondary corruption during editing**: Attempting to fix corrupted emojis in VS Code causes additional corruption with random strings inserted into headers and content lines

### Impact
- Template engines throw "Component template not found" errors
- Python code execution may fail if emojis are in comments or strings
- Markdown documentation becomes unreadable
- Report generation fails silently
- File content becomes unreadable and unparseable
- **VS Code editing makes corruption worse**: Manual fixes in the editor cause further file damage
- Data corruption requires manual restoration from version control
- **Editor becomes unusable** for files containing corrupted emojis

## Reproduction Steps

1. Create files with emoji characters in various formats:
   
   **Jinja2 Template (.j2):**
   ```jinja
   {# Template comment #}
   {% if is_text %}
   📈 MARKET PRESENCE ANALYSIS
   {{ '=' * 50 }}
   ```
   
   **Python Source (.py):**
   ```python
   def analyze_data():
       """
       📊 Data analysis function
       💼 Business logic implementation
       """
       icon = "📈"  # Trend indicator
   ```
   
   **Markdown Documentation (.md):**
   ```markdown
   ## 📊 Analytics Overview
   ### 🎯 Key Features
   - 📈 Performance tracking
   - 💡 Strategic insights
   ```

2. Edit the files in VS Code with GitHub Copilot active
3. Save and reopen the files
4. Observe corruption patterns across all file types:
   - Emoji characters display as `�`
   - Content sections are duplicated with garbled text
   - File structure becomes malformed
5. **Attempt to manually fix emojis in VS Code** (THIS MAKES IT WORSE)
6. Observe secondary corruption:
   - Random strings inserted into headers
   - Line breaks appear in unexpected places
   - Content becomes further garbled
   - File structure deteriorates beyond initial corruption

## Expected Behavior
- Emoji characters should render correctly in the editor
- File content should remain intact
- No corruption should occur during editing or saving

## Actual Behavior

### Before Corruption:
```jinja
{# Market presence analysis component #}
{% if is_text %}
📈 MARKET PRESENCE ANALYSIS
{{ '=' * 50 }}
📅 Quarterly Trends:
{% for trend in quarterly_trends %}
   {{ trend.quarter }}: {{ trend.opportunities }} opportunities
{% endfor %}
{% endif %}
```

### After Corruption:
```jinja
{# Market presence analysis component #}
{% if is_text %}
� MARKET PRESENCE ANALYSIS
{{ '=' * 50 }}
📅 Quarterly Trends:
{% for trend in quarterly_trends %}
   {{ trend.quarter }}: {{ trend.opportunities }} opportunities
{% endfor %}ET PRESENCE ANALYSIS
{{ '-' * 40 }}MARKET PRESENCE ANALYSIS
{{ '-' * 40 }}arket presence analysis component #}
{% if is_text %}
📈 MARKET PRESENCE ANALYSIS
{{ '-' * 35 }}
```

### After Attempting VS Code Manual Fix (WORSE):
```jinja
{# Market presence analysis component #}
{% if is_text %}
📈 MARKETrandom_string_here PRESENCE ANALYSIS
{{ '=' * 50 }}
📅 Quarterly 
Trends:
{% for trend in quarterly_trends %}
   {{ trend.quarter }}: {{ trend.opportunities }} opportunities
{% endfor %}ET PRESENCE ANALYSIS
{{ '-' * 40 }}MARKET PRESgarbled_textENCE ANALYSIS
{{ '-' * 40 }}arket presence analysis component #}
{% if is_text %}
📈 MARKET PRESENCE ANALYSISextra_corruption_here
{{ '-' * 35 }}
```

## Files Affected
Multiple file types across the competitive intelligence system were corrupted:

**Jinja2 Templates:**
- `templates/competitive/components/market_presence_analysis.j2`
- `templates/shared/components/statistical_analysis.j2`
- `templates/competitive/components/recommendations.j2`
- `templates/shared/components/data_quality_assessment.j2`

**Python Source Files:**
- `services/shared/base/report_segments.py` (emoji in icon variables)

**Markdown Documentation:**
- `README.md` (emoji in directory structure documentation)

**Pattern**: Any file containing emoji characters regardless of file type or syntax highlighting

## Error Messages
**Template Engine Errors:**
```
Error: Component template 'market_presence_analysis' not found
Error: Component template 'statistical_analysis' not found
Error: Component template 'recommendations' not found
Error: Component template 'data_quality_assessment' not found
```

**Python Runtime Errors** (potential):
```
SyntaxError: invalid character in identifier (when emoji corruption affects variable names)
UnicodeDecodeError: 'utf-8' codec can't decode (when corruption affects string literals)
```

**VS Code Editor Corruption** (when attempting manual fixes):
```
File becomes progressively more corrupted when editing in VS Code
Random text insertion: "📈 MARKETrandom_string_here PRESENCE ANALYSIS"
Unexpected line breaks: Headers split across multiple lines
Content fragmentation: Words broken mid-sentence
```

**Global Fix Command:**
```bash
# Search all affected file types
find . -type f \( -name "*.py" -o -name "*.j2" -o -name "*.md" -o -name "*.txt" \) -exec grep -l "�" {} \;
```

**⚠️ CRITICAL: VS Code Cannot Be Used for Manual Fixes**
```bash
# DO NOT attempt to fix corrupted emojis in VS Code - this causes additional corruption
# Must use external tools like sed, vim, or restore from version control
# VS Code editing introduces random strings and line breaks into files
```

## Workaround Applied
Manual restoration using `sed` commands to fix broken emojis across file types:

**Jinja2 Templates:**
```bash
# Fix broken chart emoji
sed -i '' 's/� MARKET PRESENCE ANALYSIS/📈 MARKET PRESENCE ANALYSIS/g' file.j2

# Fix broken analysis emoji  
sed -i '' 's/� STATISTICAL ANALYSIS/📊 STATISTICAL ANALYSIS/g' file.j2

# Fix broken recommendation emoji
sed -i '' 's/� STRATEGIC RECOMMENDATIONS/💡 STRATEGIC RECOMMENDATIONS/g' file.j2
```

**Python Source Files:**
```bash
# Fix broken business icon
sed -i '' 's/icon = "�"/icon = "💼"/g' report_segments.py

# Fix broken trend icon
sed -i '' 's/trend_icon = "�"/trend_icon = "📈"/g' report_segments.py
```

**Markdown Documentation:**
```bash
# Fix broken analytics emoji
sed -i '' 's/│       ├── � analytics\//│       ├── 📊 analytics\//g' README.md
```

**Markdown Rendering Issues:**
- Headers with broken emojis don't render properly
- Table of contents generation fails
- Documentation becomes unreadable

## Technical Analysis

### Character Encoding Issues
- Original emoji: `📈` (U+1F4C8 CHART WITH UPWARDS TREND)
- Corrupted display: `�` (U+FFFD REPLACEMENT CHARACTER)
- File corruption includes content duplication and structural damage

### Pattern Recognition
All corrupted files show the same pattern regardless of file type:
1. Emoji characters at start of lines/headers become `�`
2. Content sections get duplicated with fragment text
3. File structure becomes unparseable
4. Affects Python strings, Jinja2 templates, Markdown headers, and plain text
5. **VS Code editing causes progressive degradation**: Each edit attempt inserts random strings
6. **Random text insertion**: Headers become "📈 MARKETrandom_string_here PRESENCE"
7. **Unexpected line breaks**: Content splits mid-word or mid-header
8. Requires complete restoration from version control - **VS Code cannot be used for fixes**

## Suggested Fix
1. **Improve emoji rendering** in VS Code's text engine across all file types
2. **Validate file integrity** before saving when emoji characters are detected
3. **Add encoding detection** to prevent corruption during text processing
4. **Implement corruption detection** with automatic recovery suggestions
5. **File-type agnostic solution** since issue affects multiple syntax highlighters

## Business Impact
- **Development workflow disruption**: 4+ hours spent diagnosing and fixing corruption
- **Report generation failures**: Critical business intelligence reports failed to generate
- **Data integrity concerns**: Silent corruption could affect production systems
- **Version control noise**: Multiple corruption/restoration cycles create commit pollution

## Additional Context
This issue appears to be a **systemic problem** with VS Code's handling of emoji characters across multiple file types when GitHub Copilot is active. The corruption is:

- **File-type agnostic**: Affects Python, Jinja2, Markdown, and text files equally
- **Persistent**: Corruption survives editor restarts and file reloads
- **Silent**: No warnings or error messages during corruption
- **Structural**: Not just display issues, but actual file content corruption
- **Reproducible**: Consistently occurs when editing emoji-containing files
- **Progressive**: VS Code editing makes corruption progressively worse
- **Random text insertion**: Attempting fixes introduces arbitrary strings into content
- **Unusable for recovery**: VS Code cannot be used to fix corrupted files

**Total Files Corrupted**: 6 files across 4 different file types
**Recovery Method**: Manual `sed` commands + version control restoration
**Time Investment**: 4+ hours of debugging and manual fixes

---

**Priority**: Critical  
**Severity**: High (causes silent data corruption across multiple file types)  
**Frequency**: Reproducible with any emoji-containing file  
**Scope**: Cross-platform file corruption issue  
**Workaround**: Manual restoration using command-line tools

title: Support a notification when chat response has finished

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

labels.name: unreleased
labels.description: Patch has not yet been released in VS Code Insiders

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

## Description

VS Code has `chat.notifyWindowOnConfirmation` for when Copilot Chat needs user confirmation, but no equivalent for when agent mode finishes executing multi-step tasks. Agent mode is most valuable when users are able to be productive in other ways while it is executing. However, value is lost if users must manually keep checking for execution completion during long-running agent sessions.

## Proposed Solution

Add a setting called `chat.notifyWindowOnCompletion` (boolean, default `false`) (similar to `chat.notifyWindowOnConfirmation`) to show OS notifications when agent/edit mode execution finishes.

## Expected Behavior

-  Desktop notification when agent/edit mode completes (successfully or with errors)
-  The notification should include a basic status ("Copilot completed" or "Copilot finished with errors")
-  Clicking the notification brings VS Code to the foreground with focus in the chat window

## Use Case

Long-running agent sessions, e.g. with tool usage and multi-file changes.

## Related Issues

-  Similar to existing `chat.notifyWindowOnConfirmation` setting
-  #141506
-  #251621

title: Copilot agent reports premature command completion (~10s timeout) while commands still running in terminal

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue identified by VS Code Team member as probable bug

labels.name: chat-terminal
labels.description: The run in terminal tool in chat

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
## Environment
- Plugin: GitHub Copilot for Visual Studio Code 1.352.1715
- Editor: Visual Studio Code 1.103.0-insider
- Operating System: Darwin 24.5.0 (x64)
- Feature (e.g. agent/edit/ask mode): agent
- Selected model (e.g. GPT 4.1, Claude 3.7 Sonnet): Claude 4.0 Sonnet
- Shell: bash 5.2.15 and zsh 5.9
- Terminal: VS Code integrated terminal

## Issue Description
GitHub Copilot agent incorrectly reports command completion for long-running commands while they are still executing in the terminal.

## Steps to Reproduce
1. Start a conversation with GitHub Copilot agent
2. Request execution of a longer-running command like `npm run format` or `npm run lint`
3. Observe that the chat state changes to `waiting` briefly
4. After approximately 10 seconds, Copilot declares the command completed successfully
5. Check the actual terminal - the command is still running

## Expected Behavior
- Copilot should wait for actual command completion before reporting success
- Should accurately detect real command exit status
- Should capture complete command output

## Actual Behavior
- Copilot reports premature command completion (~10 seconds timeout)
- Shows "success" status while command still executing
- May miss actual command failures that occur after the timeout

## Technical Details Attempted
### Shell Integration Configuration
- Manually configured VS Code shell integration in `~/.bashrc`
- Added shell integration path: `$(code --locate-shell-integration-path bash)`
- Resolved `noclobber` conflicts that were preventing shell integration
- Confirmed `$TERM_PROGRAM=vscode` and shell integration variables are set
- Terminal decorations enabled: `"terminal.integrated.shellIntegration.decorationsEnabled": "both"`

### Commands Tested
- `npm run format` (ESLint + remark, ~30-60 seconds)
- `npm run lint` (ESLint only, ~15-30 seconds)  
- `npm run build` (Vite build, variable duration)
- `git log --oneline -10` (shorter command, works correctly)

### Shells Tested
- bash 5.2.15 with manual shell integration
- zsh 5.9 with shell integration
- Both exhibit same premature completion behavior

### VS Code Settings Applied
```json
{
  "terminal.integrated.shellIntegration.enabled": true,
  "terminal.integrated.shellIntegration.decorationsEnabled": "both", 
  "terminal.integrated.shellIntegration.showCommandGuide": true,
  "terminal.integrated.stickyScroll.enabled": true,
  "terminal.integrated.enablePersistentSessions": true,
  "terminal.integrated.defaultProfile.osx": "bash"
}
```

## Workaround Attempts
1. **Enhanced npm scripts with completion echo**: Added `&& echo '✅ Command completed successfully'` to scripts - still reports early completion
2. **Explicit shell integration setup**: Manually configured shell integration - no improvement
3. **Different shell configurations**: Tested bash and zsh - same issue
4. **Command chaining**: Used `command && echo "DONE"` pattern - Copilot still times out early

## Expected Fix
Copilot agent should:
1. Properly integrate with VS Code's shell integration to detect real command completion
2. Respect actual command exit codes and timing
3. Wait for shell integration's command completion signals rather than using arbitrary timeouts
4. Handle commands that take longer than 10 seconds without false positive completion

## Impact
This affects developer workflow when using Copilot agent for:
- Build processes
- Linting/formatting operations  
- Test suites
- Any command taking longer than ~10 seconds

The premature completion reporting makes it difficult to rely on Copilot agent for longer development tasks.

## Shell Configuration Files

### ~/.bashrc (Enhanced with VS Code shell integration)
```bash
# ---------- ~/.bashrc ----------
# interactive only
case $- in *i*) ;; *) return ;; esac

# oh-my-bash
export OSH='/usr/local/share/oh-my-bash'
export THEME="$HOME/.bash/themes/agnoster-bash/agnoster.bash"

[[ -f "$OSH/oh-my-bash.sh" ]] && source "$OSH/oh-my-bash.sh"

# VS Code Insiders integration - silence notarisation error
codei() { command code-insiders "$@" 2> >(grep -v 'SecCodeCheckValidity' >&2); }
alias code=codei

# completions / plugins
completions=(git composer ssh)
aliases=(general)
plugins=(git npm bashmarks)

# python alias

# GPG
export GPG_TTY=$(tty)

# PATH additions
export PATH="$HOME/.rd/bin:$PATH"

# nvm
export NVM_DIR="$HOME/.nvm"
[ -s "$NVM_DIR/nvm.sh" ] && . "$NVM_DIR/nvm.sh"
[ -s "$NVM_DIR/bash_completion" ] && . "$NVM_DIR/bash_completion"

# cargo
[ -f "$HOME/.cargo/env" ] && . "$HOME/.cargo/env"

# electron-forge completion
EFCOMP="$HOME/Documents/git/lui/plat-lui-portal-1/node_modules/tabtab/.completions/electron-forge.bash"
[ -f "$EFCOMP" ] && . "$EFCOMP"

# local bin
[ -f "$HOME/.local/bin/env" ] && . "$HOME/.local/bin/env"

# VS Code shell integration - enhanced with better command detection
if [[ "$TERM_PROGRAM" == "vscode" ]]; then
  # Temporarily disable noclobber for shell integration
  _noclobber_was_set=false
  if [[ -o noclobber ]]; then
    _noclobber_was_set=true
    set +o noclobber
  fi
  
  # Get and source the shell integration script (try insiders first, then regular)
  _vscode_shim="$(command code-insiders --locate-shell-integration-path bash 2>/dev/null || command code --locate-shell-integration-path bash 2>/dev/null)"
  if [ -n "$_vscode_shim" ] && [ -f "$_vscode_shim" ]; then
    . "$_vscode_shim"
  fi
  
  # Restore noclobber if it was originally set
  if [ "$_noclobber_was_set" = true ]; then
    set -o noclobber
  fi
  
  # Enhanced command detection function
  _vscode_command_complete() {
    local exit_code=$?
    echo "Command completed with exit code: $exit_code" >&2
    return $exit_code
  }
  
  # Override common commands for better detection
  alias npm='command npm'
  alias git='command git'
  
  unset _vscode_shim _noclobber_was_set
fi
```

## Logs

### How to Collect Logs
1. Open VS Code Command Palette (`Cmd+Shift+P`)
2. Type: `Developer: Show Logs`
3. Select relevant logs:

### Key Log Locations

### Expected Log Entries to Look For

This demonstrates the exact issue: Copilot agent reports command completion while the actual lint process is still running in the terminal.

title: Make terminal auto approve more aware of paths
body:
When configuring terminal auto approval, users expect path variations to work intuitively. Previously, if you approved `bin/foo`, it would only match that exact path separator style, requiring separate entries for Windows and Unix variants.

This change makes the auto approval system path-aware by detecting strings that contain path separators (`/` or `\`) and creating flexible regex patterns that handle common path variations:

**Before:**
```json
{
  "terminal.integrated.autoApprove": {
    "bin/foo": true,
    "bin\\foo": true,     // Required separate entry
    "./bin/foo": true,    // Required separate entry  
    ".\\bin\\foo": true   // Required separate entry
  }
}
```

**After:**
```json
{
  "terminal.integrated.autoApprove": {
    "bin/foo": true  // Now matches all variations automatically
  }
}
```

With this change, approving `bin/foo` automatically allows:
- `bin/foo` (exact match)
- `bin\foo` (Windows backslashes)
- `./bin/foo` (current directory with forward slash)
- `.\bin\foo` (current directory with backslash)
- Mixed separator combinations

The implementation:
1. Detects path-like strings by checking for `/` or `\` separators
2. Creates flexible regex patterns using character classes `[/\\]` for separators
3. Adds optional prefix matching for `./` and `.\` patterns
4. Preserves existing behavior for non-path commands (like `echo`, `ls`)
5. Properly escapes regex special characters in path names

This makes the terminal auto approval feature more intuitive for cross-platform development workflows where the same logical path might be referenced with different separator styles.

Fixes #259672.

title: Add safe readonly commands to terminal auto approve defaults
body:
This PR adds a comprehensive set of safe and common readonly commands to the terminal auto approve defaults, improving the user experience by automatically approving commonly used commands that don't modify system state.

## Changes Made

### Added Safe Commands (Auto-approved by default)
**Unix/Linux commands (16):**
- `echo`, `ls`, `pwd`, `cat`, `head`, `tail`, `grep`, `find`, `which`, `whoami`, `date`, `hostname`, `ps`, `wc`, `sort`, `uniq`

**PowerShell commands (7):**
- `Get-ChildItem`, `Get-Content`, `Get-Location`, `Get-Date`, `Get-Host`, `Get-Process`, `Get-Service`

PowerShell commands use case-insensitive regex patterns (e.g., `/^Get-ChildItem\\b/i`) to match variations like `get-childitem` or `GET-CHILDITEM`.

### Preserved Security
All existing dangerous commands remain denied by default:
- `rm`, `rmdir`, `del`, `kill`, `curl`, `wget`, `eval`, `chmod`, `chown`, `Remove-Item`

### Testing
Added comprehensive test suite covering:
- All new safe commands with various arguments
- Case-insensitive PowerShell command matching
- Dangerous command denial behavior
- Configuration override functionality

## Example Usage

With these defaults, users will no longer need explicit approval for common operations like:

```bash
# These commands are now auto-approved
echo "Hello world"
ls -la
pwd
cat README.md
grep "TODO" *.js
Get-ChildItem C:\
Get-Content file.txt
```

While still requiring approval for potentially dangerous operations:

```bash
# These still require explicit approval
rm important-file.txt
del *.exe
kill 1234
Remove-Item folder -Recurse
```

Users can still override any default by explicitly setting commands to `true` or `false` in their `chat.tools.terminal.autoApprove` configuration.

Fixes #259668.
